Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Cosmological All-wavelength Radiative Transfer (CART)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This group will investigate how the light of newly-forming galaxies and the active nuclei of galaxies propagates through the intergalactic gas. They focus attention on a period that ended about a billion years into cosmic history, when the neutral intergalactic gas was ionized by the ultraviolet light of galaxies. To calculate how gas and dark matter came together to make the galaxies, the group will use hydrodynamic simulations. They will develop and refine their calculations to predict when a galaxy should form stars, or develop an active nucleus. Then, the photons emerging from the galaxy will be tracked using Dr. Li's 3-dimensional radiative-transfer code. That code will be improved to handle Lyman-alpha photons, ionization, and the effect of very small dust grains. The group will produce large mock catalogs of high-redshift galaxies and quasars that describe their emission from X-ray to millimeter wavelengths, and include the hydrogen lines at 21cm and Lyman alpha.

Two graduate students will be trained by participating in the research. The new radiative-transfer code, and the mock catalogs, will be made available to the astronomical community. Those catalogs summarize the predictions of our theories about how galaxies grow. This group and others will test those theories by comparing the catalogs with what is seen in current and planned deep surveys of distant galaxies. Both Dr. Li and Dr. Abel work at institutions with strong records in public outreach, and this project will yield attractive still images and movies to illustrate current ideas about galaxy formation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report of AST-0965694

Award AST-0965694, titled ``Cosmological All-wavelength Radiative Transfer (CART)'', for the period of 08/15/2009 -- 06/30/2012, is a collaborative project between PIs Dr. Yuexing Li from Penn State University and Dr. Tom Abel from  Stanford University. The project goal was to improve the 3-D Monte Carlo radiative transfer code, ART^2, originally developed by Li et al in 2008, by implementing three new modules, including ionization of hydrogen and emission lines of Lyman-alpha and molecules. A postdoc, Dr. Hidenobu Yajima supported by this grant to work on ART^2 at PSU.

To date, thanks to support from this award, we have completed a state-of-the-art radiative transfer code ART^2. It is currently the only code available that has the following essential features: 

1. It couples Lyman-alpha resonant scattering, molecular emission lines (e.g., CO), ionization of neutral hydrogen, and multi-wavelength continuum from X-ray to radio.

2. It employs an adaptive grid scheme in 3-D Cartesian coordinates, which handles an arbitrary geometry and covers a large dynamic range over several orders of magnitude. Such a grid is critical in resolving the clumpy, highly inhomogeneous density field in the radiative transfer calculations.

3. It adopts a two-phase ISM model in which the cold, dense clouds are embedded in a hot, diffuse medium in pressure equilibrium. In the case where hydrodynamic simulations have insufficient resolution to resolve the multi-phase ISM, this model ensures an appropriate prescription of the ISM physics, which is important for studying dust properties in galaxies.  

4. It follows the radiation from stars and accreting black holes, and calculates the scattering, absorption, ionization, and re-emission of the surrounding medium. It efficiently and self-consistently produces spectral energy distributions and images in a full spectrum that includes both continuum and emission lines.

Owing to these features, ART^2 is considered as one of the most sophisticated and versatile radiative transfer codes available, with a wide range of research applications addressing the multi-wavelength properties of galaxies and quasars. It can also be applied to planetary or stellar systems to derive observational signatures of embedded protoplanets and young stars. We're developing a website, http://www.astro.psu.edu/~yuexing/ART2/, to release ART^2 to the public.

In the CART project, we combined multi-scale cosmological simulations with multi-wavelength radiative transfer calculations to study galaxies from the cosmic dawn to the present day. It has so far resulted in 8 papers in publication and 4 in preparation. Here's a list of our findings from this project:

(1) The coupling of Continuum, Emission Lines, and Ionization in ART^2, together with an adaptive refinement grid, enables a self-consistent and accurate calculation of the Lya, molecular lines, and multi-band properties (Yajima et al 2012A, Li et al 2012A).

(2) Progenitors of the Milky Way at high redshifts appear to be Lya emitters (Yajima2012B).

(3) Cold accretion may play an important role in the early growth phase of distant galaxies, and that Lya may be one of the most powerful tools to detect it (Yajima et al 2012C).

(4) We developed a merger model for extended Lya blobs, that interacting galaxies at high redshifts may produce the extended Lya blobs as observed (Yajima et al 2012D).

(5) Photon trapping may have a significant impact on the Lyman-alpha properties of star-forming galaxies (Yajima et al 2012E).

(6) Lyman-alpha scattering plays a dominant role in producing the 21 cm signals from objects in the epoch of reionization, and those of the first stars, galaxies and quasars show disctinct structures (Yajima et al 2012F).
